FRIDAY, MARCH 19, 1937

The Coming Strike
While plans are being drawn up for this year's
strike against war, it is essential that all campus organizations meet, discuss their possible participation, and
choose a delegate for the next meeting on the Monday
when we return to school at 12.20 in Levering Hall
Board Room.
We, supporting this strike, wish to make the basis
of this demonstration as broad as possible and to enlist
the backing of every group affiliated with the Hopkins.
This will be a strike that is general, and we hope effective, manifestation of student sentiment against war.

"Teaching is not a one-club game. The teacher who
uses only a single technique is no further along than
iv the golfer who plays the entire course with a single
club." Prof. Guy M. Wilson of Boston University's
of education recommends diversity of technique minus
the clubs.

New York Alumni Spirit
The Musical Club's trip to New York uncovered an
element which many Hopkins students have thought
dormant, that of an alumnus school spirit. Sponsored
by the Hopkins club of New York City, the concert was
a huge success due to the efforts of that organization,
and the audience, largely of Hopkins graduates, was
the most genial and enthusiastic that the club encountered in its entire season. The alumni organization arranged to put the musical group up at the
Warwick Hotel, the scene of the concert.
The whole affair showed a living spirit in the Hopkins on the part of those residents of New York who
have left Hopkins halls and who retain memories of
the days spent here, and wanted to show it in a way
that would touch personally the undergraduates of
today.
So congenial was the relationship struck up between
the alumni and undergraduates, and so successful was
the concert itself, that assurance was given the affair
would be repeated in years to come.

An Important Struggle
Dr. Sigerist's talk on Spain brought to light some
phases of the situation that most of us are inclined to
omit in judging the situation.
In the first place to clearly appreciate the recent
events one must study the history of Spain for centuries
back and the series of development w'hich led to the
peculiar position of Spain today. This background was
sketched admirably by the speaker.
Another piece of information little realized are the
remarkable cultural advances made by the government
In spite of the bloody conflict within such proximity.
The special batallion appointed by the government is
endeavoring to save works of art and protect nonfighting men of learning and art. Exhibits and new
theaters are being formed. Over twenty-five thousand
students are now being trained for the teaching profession in the normal schools demonstrating the clear
faith and confidence the people of Spain possess in the
democratic

This strike against war is a means of deminstrating to the world just how the most potential cannon
fodder feels about ending our lives in some unmarked
grave, about living physically and mentally shellshocked or gassed. We may differ as to the solution to
the problem of war; but that we all oppose this devastating and damnable threat to civilization, we all
agree.
And that is why we should all support this strike.
"The college, as a producer of adults, should shift
emphasis from future values to the significance of
present experiences. The terrible discount on present
values is akin to the evils of hoarding. Life in college
is as real as life anywhere." Pres. Henry M. Wriston of
Brown University asks student to "Wake Up And
Live" in the present.

A Matter Of Honor
Our attention has been called to the unauthorized
wearing of Hopkins athletic letters by a few students
on the campus.
These students should recognize and respect the
Insignia of the University and realize that only those
who have earned and who were awarded these honors
should b entitled to wear them. It is not only violating
the letter of Athletic Association (a student organization) but the spirit and honor of the Hopkins Athletic
system.
This matter is also part and parcel of the honor system, guarded by the Student Council. Any student who
wears an athletic award he did not earn is cheating
and lowering the dignity of those entitled to these
honors.
We feel certain that the few men we have in mind
do not comprehend the true significance of their actions;
we hope that they reflect on this matter and act
accordingly.

You are on the train, comfortably
snuggled down in a brush-like plush
seat when you realize that the ski
tips were left home. Much shaking
of heads follows this discovery and
instead of getting the rest of last
night's sleep, you are told how to prevent your skis from breaking.
There is only one way to get rid
of the people who are hanging on your
neck and telling you what to do when
you get up in the ski fields. You
merely get up and walk down the
aisle, turn left and stay there until
you feel reasonably sure that they
have gone back to their seats. (But
don't feel too sure about that. There,
is nothing a dyed-in-the-wool skier
likes to do more than to talk.)

Nothing is certain in philosophy, says Will Durant,
therefore philosophers do not go to war.
A hot and furious tongue battle has been going on in
recent weeks among such famed educators as John
Dewey, Robert M. Hutchins, and that frequent visitor
in Alfred, Dixon Ryan Fox.
Dewey calls Hutchins half-educated. Hutchins says
Dewey can't read. Fox disparages the university which
Hutchins heads. Late Monday Hutchins was still
marshalling his forces for a counter-attack.
Now each of these men, since he influences a system
of education, is an educator; and since an eductional
system presupposes a philosophy, each may be assumed
to be a philosopher.
Yet the vituperative word-war which we have noted
would appear to be contrary to philosophical practice;
and the college student, who has an incomplete understanding of such matters, is hard pressed to find an
explanation.
He can scarcely be blamed for wondering if some of
these educational philosophers have not permitted objctivity to be obscured by a much less praiseworthy
desire for supremacy.
If this be the case, then what has become of the
open-mindedness which is supposed to keep philosophers
from one another's throats?
And if eminent educators are moved by selfish ambition to wrangle like undergraduates, whom are we to
regard as models?
—Alfred University Fiat Lux

FRIDAY, MARCH 19, 1937

The Coming Strike
While plans are being drawn up for this year's
strike against war, it is essential that all campus organizations meet, discuss their possible participation, and
choose a delegate for the next meeting on the Monday
when we return to school at 12.20 in Levering Hall
Board Room.
We, supporting this strike, wish to make the basis
of this demonstration as broad as possible and to enlist
the backing of every group affiliated with the Hopkins.
This will be a strike that is general, and we hope effective, manifestation of student sentiment against war.

"Teaching is not a one-club game. The teacher who
uses only a single technique is no further along than
iv the golfer who plays the entire course with a single
club." Prof. Guy M. Wilson of Boston University's
of education recommends diversity of technique minus
the clubs.

New York Alumni Spirit
The Musical Club's trip to New York uncovered an
element which many Hopkins students have thought
dormant, that of an alumnus school spirit. Sponsored
by the Hopkins club of New York City, the concert was
a huge success due to the efforts of that organization,
and the audience, largely of Hopkins graduates, was
the most genial and enthusiastic that the club encountered in its entire season. The alumni organization arranged to put the musical group up at the
Warwick Hotel, the scene of the concert.
The whole affair showed a living spirit in the Hopkins on the part of those residents of New York who
have left Hopkins halls and who retain memories of
the days spent here, and wanted to show it in a way
that would touch personally the undergraduates of
today.
So congenial was the relationship struck up between
the alumni and undergraduates, and so successful was
the concert itself, that assurance was given the affair
would be repeated in years to come.

An Important Struggle
Dr. Sigerist's talk on Spain brought to light some
phases of the situation that most of us are inclined to
omit in judging the situation.
In the first place to clearly appreciate the recent
events one must study the history of Spain for centuries
back and the series of development w'hich led to the
peculiar position of Spain today. This background was
sketched admirably by the speaker.
Another piece of information little realized are the
remarkable cultural advances made by the government
In spite of the bloody conflict within such proximity.
The special batallion appointed by the government is
endeavoring to save works of art and protect nonfighting men of learning and art. Exhibits and new
theaters are being formed. Over twenty-five thousand
students are now being trained for the teaching profession in the normal schools demonstrating the clear
faith and confidence the people of Spain possess in the

This strike against war is a means of deminstrating to the world just how the most potential cannon

And that is why we should all support this strike.
"The college, as a producer of adults, should shift
emphasis from future values to the significance of
present experiences. The terrible discount on present
values is akin to the evils of hoarding. Life in college
is as real as life anywhere." Pres. Henry M. Wriston of
Brown University asks student to "Wake Up And
Live" in the present.

A Matter Of Honor
Our attention has been called to the unauthorized
wearing of Hopkins athletic letters by a few students
on the campus.
These students should recognize and respect the
Insignia of the University and realize that only those
who have earned and who were awarded these honors
should b entitled to wear them. It is not only violating
the letter of Athletic Association (a student organization) but the spirit and honor of the Hopkins Athletic
system.
This matter is also part and parcel of the honor system, guarded by the Student Council. Any student who
wears an athletic award he did not earn is cheating
and lowering the dignity of those entitled to these
honors.
We feel certain that the few men we have in mind
do not comprehend the true significance of their actions;
we hope that they reflect on this matter and act
accordingly.

You are on the train, comfortably
snuggled down in a brush-like plush
seat when you realize that the ski
tips were left home. Much shaking
of heads follows this discovery and
instead of getting the rest of last
night's sleep, you are told how to prevent your skis from breaking.
There is only one way to get rid
of the people who are hanging on your
neck and telling you what to do when
you get up in the ski fields. You
merely get up and walk down the
aisle, turn left and stay there until
you feel reasonably sure that they
have gone back to their seats. (But
don't feel too sure about that. There,
is nothing a dyed-in-the-wool skier
likes to do more than to talk.)

When you come back, the Washington crowd has come aboard, and
since there are a great many skiers
from the diplomatic circles, the train
has taken on a cosmopolitan air.

being screamed about your head.

Nothing is certain in philosophy, says Will Durant,
therefore philosophers do not go to war.
A hot and furious tongue battle has been going on in
recent weeks among such famed educators as John
Dewey, Robert M. Hutchins, and that frequent visitor
in Alfred, Dixon Ryan Fox.
Dewey calls Hutchins half-educated. Hutchins says
Dewey can't read. Fox disparages the university which
Hutchins heads. Late Monday Hutchins was still
marshalling his forces for a counter-attack.
Now each of these men, since he influences a system
of education, is an educator; and since an eductional
system presupposes a philosophy, each may be assumed
to be a philosopher.
Yet the vituperative word-war which we have noted
would appear to be contrary to philosophical practice;
and the college student, who has an incomplete understanding of such matters, is hard pressed to find an
explanation.
He can scarcely be blamed for wondering if some of
these educational philosophers have not permitted objctivity to be obscured by a much less praiseworthy
desire for supremacy.
If this be the case, then what has become of the
open-mindedness which is supposed to keep philosophers
from one another's throats?
And if eminent educators are moved by selfish ambition to wrangle like undergraduates, whom are we to
regard as models?
—Alfred University Fiat Lux
